young people are smarter than we think

I think these young people have been

uh wealth enormous power enormous
opportunity uh the least well off of
them is considerably better than the

recognize that they see the signs of

opulence on every hand they are
surrounded uh by sensation they are

surrounded by uh uh politics none of
these are capable of delivering the
goods and I think they recognize that
and I think there is a desire to find
something that will last something that
will endure something that will not
disappoint and when you do that
inevitably you are tempted to turn back

age uh to something that might not seem
to have appealed to you in your earlier
phase but your earlier phase you
recognized was a deceitful and deceptive
one you ask Harvard graduates where
they're all going and they're all going
to go 90% of the seniors in any given
class say they're going to three cities
they're going to go to Washington to put
things right power they're going to go

fantasy and I think they come back from

that like ours there's no there there uh
Washington is not going to turn the

New York doesn't spare it the troubles
and tribulations of living in New York
and all the fantasy from La La Land
doesn't dull the pain of living in a

that's a modest symbol I think people
say okay there must be another way maybe
Jerusalem is the place uh maybe uh uh
pilgrimage to a holy city is the place
maybe some ashram somewhere maybe

there are wiser people than we who years

maybe we even heard them in our youth
and maybe the trick is to try to
recapture recover some of that for
ourselves now I think that's part of the
excitement well among the things that I
find that I have to say to young people
which is a strange sort of conundrum is
I have to tell them that they are of
value they suffer not from a high
self-esteem they suffer by and large
from low self-esteem they tend to
believe they are the result of this
materialistic mendacious
culture uh when I am sitting down with
young couples to be married I always ask
them would you like your marriage to
resemble that of your parents invariably
they say no thank you very much
I love my parents presumably they love
each other but we hope for something
better than this so there is a sense
that they recognize the limitations of
the world in which they are they tend to
overemphasize their own limitations and
part of my job is uh to say you can
aspire to be more than the sum total of
your parts there's more to you than just
a brain or just a body or just a a set
of marketable
skills and I find rather than trying to
deflate their ego uh part of my job is
try to raise it up so that they can
understand that they are in the biblical
phrase created a little lower than the
angels have been given great power to
represent God incarnate in the world
that we are images made in God's image
that there are great things that we can

raised families say if you're not doing
do it for yourself do it for your
children for heaven's sakes uh let them
Blossom and flourish I try to reassure

present males nor are they the first

certain degree of intellectual humility
that has to be introduced here oh things

Rich history but the great line for me

nearly all of the Balor sermons that I
give and I give a lot of these across
the country in Romans
12 St Paul yells with almost literally
off the page do not be conformed to this
world but be transformed by the renewing
of your mind and I say those of you who
are privileged to be members of a great
University like this and who have had
your minds renewed even if you didn't do
much about the renewal yourself that
simply being here has been a part of
this process you have an opportunity and
an obligation to be agents of
transformation out there to make things
better than they are to make a
difference to find your place and to
exercise that it may take you a few
years it may take you the rest of your
life
but as John bunan points out in B his
progress that's a life worth living a
life in pursuit of some worthwhile
ultimate maybe even unattainable goal
you should do that and some of them say
oh I couldn't possibly do that and of
course my reply is well why couldn't you
what talent do you lack what opportunity
is missing what skills do you think you
need in order to do that and when they
start thinking about the talents the
skills that they have and the things
that they might need they begin actually
to think well what difference might I
make how could I do something like this
now uh surely that comes with more
Authority from somebody like Bill Gates
who says look I'm the richest man in the
world and I'm screwed up I didn't know
what I was doing so surely you can go
out and find something I was interested
when Bill Gates spoke at Harvard that
not many of the students with whom I
spoke said that they wanted to be the
richest man in the world they wanted to
find out given what I have my talents my
time my opportunity what can I do what
can I do to make myself a happier better
person what can I do to make my world a
happier better place and in most cases
for most people it's a relatively small
Enterprise at commencement it's
customary to say you're going to change
the world they not going to change the
world let's be realistic about this
these kids are not going to go out and
turn this tial world upside down but
there may be certain aspects of your own
life that you can attend to and certain
relationships that you can cultivate and
encourage certain places where you can
make the difference the trick is to find
those places and to do it and I think
people are searching for that looking
for that that's what we call looking for
meaning looking for wholeness most
people experience the Brokenness of the
world they want to do something about it
and my job is to encourage them to do so
